This course introduces students to the main concepts and theories of international political economy (IPE) studies, starting with the interaction between states and markets, with China and East Asia as the primary case studies. The main theories of IPE, including realism, liberalism and Marxism, as well as approaches to globalisation, will be examined at the beginning. China's Regional Neighborhood: Opportunities and Challenges for China Under Obor Initiative
China's Regional Neighborhood: Opportunities and Challenges for China Under Obor Initiative

This course will cover the regional neighborhood of China and the challenges and opportunities they will offer to China, not least due to the unprecedented economic initiative of OBOR. The OBOR initiative does not only have to manage the economic challenges in China and internationally but also economic challenges and socio-economic challenges in its neighbors but also political and security challenges in its neighbors, especially in some of its more challenged neighbors. These challenges could be both due to unstable governments, corruption but also political transition and radicalization of some governments or sub-national actors. The OBOR initiative and China's neighbors are also under a geopolitical transition and a possible power transition between U.S.-China but also Russia-China. The focus will be on Southeast Asia,, South Asia and Central Asia but other regions will be considered in this very complex and challenging environment.

The course will providea critical frame for the history and theory of international law through an exploration ofglobal governance. Global governance involves the exercise of power and authority by international organizations, private entities, and national government agencies reaching beyond a single state. The seminar addresses legal regulation of these exercises of power, including accountability requirements of transparency, participation, reason-giving, and liability (“global administrative law”). The central focus is on review mechanisms: the roles, jurisprudence, and effects of domestic courts and institutions, global tribunals and arbitration panels, global public and NGO monitoring bodies, in responding to the accountability gaps and opportunities created by globalization. What happens when global authorities review domestic governmental decisions? Should domestic courts review global institutions? Who are the winners and losers in these processes?

The integration of the nation states of Europe has represented one of the major changes in global political economy of the 20th century. But what does this involve? Is it the increase of institutional powers, as embodied in the European Union, or should it be interpreted in a wider context? Should it also embrace the processes of countries that were not members of the European union and its predecessors? Should it move outside the scope of institutional politics and embrace the movements of trade, capital and peoples? Should it not simply focus on policy-making and look more at the contexts in which the policies were made and the effects of those policies once implemented? This course will argue in favour of a wider conceptualization of ‘European integration’. Most of the traditional literature does not. It will look at major developments in 20th century European development – the background to the policies, the policies themselves and their contribution to the (perceived) results.
The Numbers We Use in International Comparisons
The Numbers We Use in International Comparisons

Not all countries are the same. Some are more populous than others; some economies are bigger; some are richer; some are grow faster; some are more equal; some are more competitive; some are better governed. To express these differences scientists have constructed numbers and used this data to demonstrate the differences between countries. Not only do they do this, but they employ these numbers to show relationships between variables and to use these relationships to ‘explain’ differences. But what do these numbers contain? Do the components really reflect the reality they are supposed to represent? How accurate are they? And, if they are not accurate, what should we do with the conclusions of the thousands of papers and articles which use them? This course will examine these questions and explore the databases of the main indicators. It will also use online modules (subtitled in Chinese) to prepare for classroom discussions.

This course will offer a comprehensive examination of an area of law that constantly gains significance and practical relevance. Few international law fields have seen an increase in literature and case law as steep as international economic law. On the one hand, in an era of increasing interdependence in international business, the WTO has built the most successful, rules-based system that aims to facilitate business transactions and trade, enforced by the strongest dispute settlement system in the history of international law. On the other hand, the existence of more than 3,000 Bilateral Investment Treaties and the constant increase of investment arbitration signal the rising significance of international investment law. Turning to the group of students to whom this module may be attractive and what they may expect to gain after completing it, this module aims to provide students with the appropriate tools to identify, discuss and critically analyse the intricacies of international economic law. It is suitable for students interested in acquiring a thorough and deep understanding of international trade and investment law. It also provides the theoretical and practical knowledge necessary for legal practitioners in the field and for those seeking to advice governmental bodies, international organisations or private companies on matters related to international trade and investment law and policy.
The External Relations of the European Union
The External Relations of the European Union

This course focuses on a vital component of the European edifice, that is, the external relations of the EU. The EU is an active player globally and participates in manifold international agreements. The course provides a thorough analysis of the relevant legal framework and offers a critical review of its efficacy. It deals first with the basic constitutional foundations of EU External Relations law, explaining when and how the EU is an international actor. Afterwards, the course will focus on the substantive policy priorities of the EU an an international actor. This course will offer a comprehensive examination of an area of law that constantly gains significance and practical relevance. The EU is an important, autonomous international player that shapes global policies and priorities. It has been a key actor in shaping major international trade, environmental agreements,. Moreover, the participation of the EU alongside its Member States in almost all international organisations raises a number of practical, for example relating to their participation and international responsibility.
Competing Regionalisms: European Union's Eastern Partnership Versus Russia's Eurasian Economic Union
Competing Regionalisms: European Union's Eastern Partnership Versus Russia's Eurasian Economic Union

Course outline:The course is aimed at students wishing to deepen their understanding of International Relations and International Politics with a particular focus to the ‘Wider Europe’ region, comprising the European Union, but also Russia and a number of post-Soviet states. More precisely, the course will concentrate on the competition of the EU and Russia over the countries of common neighbourhood (six Eastern Partnership states), mounting in the Ukraine crisis of 2013-2016. Taking the crisis in Ukraine as the point of departure, we will put this regional conflict into the broader context of the competition of the two actors (the EU and Russia) in their shared neighbourhood. It will allow students to get an in-depth understanding of the regional dynamics, understand the factors impacting the regional conflict, foresee potential conflicts, as well as analyse possible solutions. Course objectives: The objective of the course is two-fold: first, students will learn about the regional dynamics unfolding in the environment of competing regionalism (on the example of the ‘Wider Europe’ region), second, students will learn the method of comparative foreign policy analysis.

This International Relations course examines how the EU engages with the contemporary world through its foreign policy, security and development policies. The course will examine a series of case-studies of current policies within the theoretical concept of normative power. The ambitions as well as the limitations of the EU’s global role are critically assessed, including the likely impact of BREXIT. The course involves student participation, powerpoint presentations as well as a negotiation simulation exercise.

The Political Science course examines the institutional structure and key policies of the European Union and debates the nature of contemporary integration – is it still a supranational initiative to create a “United States of Europe”, or has integration returned to a more intergovernmental process where national sovereignty is dominant? In this respect the impact of BREXIT directly on the EU as well as its wider effect on popular support and Euroscepticism across the 28 member states is considered.

Course is to designed to introduce methods of visualisation and analytics of spatial geo-located data in R software. Students will practice on example of China dataset and map how to deal with polygon and point geo-located data and GIS shapefile maps. Open resources (software and maps) make it attractive because of easy access. Course does not require R software knowledge, but fundamentals of statistics or econometrics are demanded. Class 1 (4 hours): Geo-spatial data visualization: shapefile import, GIS map layers, dataset integration, full maps and zooms / cut-offs. Students will learn how to handle with spatial data and how to produce attractive maps for data analysis. Class 2 (4 hours): Spatial relations: distances between regions and points, spatial weights matrices;spatial statistics: detection of clusters, outliers and spatial heterogeneity. Students will learn how to measure the distance between points and areas, how to find neighbours and how to check similarities and dissimilarities between regions. Class 3 (4 hours): Spatial econometric models (from Mansky GNS to OLS) and spatial interactions models for dependence on distance. Students will learn how to incorporate the effects of distance and neighbourhood in econometric model and for how much it is important. Students will learn how to detect and interpret the spillovers in inter-regional relations. Class 4 (4 hours): Point geo-located data: identification, visualization, aggregation, agglomeration analysis. Students will learn how to analyze point data (like firms located in given point on the map) and what kind of information can be captured for business purposes. Students after completion of this course will be ready to produce by themselves nice maps for own data as well as to run econometric models which can incorporate over-border relations and spillovers.

Course is to designed to introduce the methods of business analysis, which are necessary in all business units. Popular spreadsheets like Microsoft Excel or WPS Office 2015 are used. Course gives practical skills of commercial analyses to be directly implemented in companies. Fundamentals of finance or statistics are demanded, but not necessary. Class 1 (4 hours): Deposits and loans in business: Future Value (FV) of investments and annuities, loans amortization schedules, loans available at given payment. Students will learn how to compare and analyse different credit products. With the use of Pivot tables they will see how to make Cash Flow of the bank. Students will discuss the problem of the interest rate for business. Class 2 (4 hours): Recency-Frequency-Value (RFV) model in Customer Relations Management (CRM), what information on customer’s loyalty is hidden in their transaction data. On the basis of purchase information students will build a model which can support selection of the best and worst customers as well as indicate the behavior of “average” customer. Class 3 (4 hours): Monte Carlo simulation for business strategy, what-if analysis in business plan, models for profits, sales, NPV and risk. On the basis of probability distributions gained from historical data, students will learn how to make a forecast of future customer and business behavior. Students will discuss possible strategies of changes in business parameters (prices, quantities, margin etc.) to improve business performance. Class 4 (4 hours): Optimisation methods with Solver for optimum production, profit maximization or cost minimization. Students will build optimization models which can help in finding the best structure of production or best transport combination. They can test with these models if changing the business parameters (prices, quantities, margin etc.) can make significant changes in production proportions or in transportation routes. Students after completion of this course will be ready to run statistical analyses on business which can reveal the information unknown before. By using popular spreadsheet software, these analyses will be easily transferable to business reality.

The course offers students an insight into the basics of European Union law. This will cover the essentials of EU history, the EU’s legal bases and law-making, main legal principles, the EU institutions and their powers, internal market law (in particular free movement of goods) and the interaction of EU Law with international and Member State law. These will be highlighted by using the specific area of environmental law as an example, including its multi-layered making and application as well as its interaction in particular with free movement of goods.

The European Union is at a crossroad. The major aim of the course is that the students will understand the history and different stages of the European integration, the economics of the EU and the basic features of the eurozone. For a better understanding of the complex idea of European integration we will start with the idea of a free trade area and develop between free trade and a common market as the EU. In a second step we will focus on monetary integration and discuss the basic preconditions of a successful common currency area.

We will first start with a review of some basic concepts in lifecontingencies, for example, mortality table, age-at-death distributionand survival model; using those, we will show how to define actuarialpresent values of insurance and annuity benefits and the relationshipbetween them.We will then see how insurance companies calculate premiums in lifeinsurance, taking into account their expenses (acquisition, maintenance,general, settlement) and their profit objective, with various premiumcalculation principles. We will define the concept of reserve for a lifeinsurance policy and how it builds up over the years, so that theinsurance company can pay the death benefit.Finally, with a multiple decrement table, we will evaluate insurancepolicies with a double indemnity death benefit or the value of death,retirement and disability benefits from a retirement plan.
An introduction to Financial Markets and Asset Allocation
An introduction to Financial Markets and Asset Allocation

The course explains the steps of the asset allocation process and how to construct aninvestment portfolio. After an introduction to financial markets and asset classes, we willfirst look at the asset allocation process itself. We start with a long-term portfolio (thestrategic asset allocation) and move to short term deviations from it (tactical assetallocation). We will also look at how to evaluate the success of the portfolio investments.The aim of the course is to give students a basic understanding of financial markets andguidance on how to construct a portfolio from a longer-term perspective rather than justspeculating in the short term. It is therefore useful for individuals managing their ownmoney, as well as for those who want to work in the financial sector. Level: Bachelor

Behavioural finance is sometimes called ‘finance for normal people’, whereas classicalfinance is called ‘finance for rational people’. Since people are rather normal thanrational, behavioural finance has become an established field. We will learn why investorsare sometimes unable to behave in a rational way (‘limits to arbitrage’). This will beexplained based on real-world examples. Furthermore we discuss the impact ofpsychology on financial decisions, using some class experiments. Finally we will discussa new approach – adaptive market hypothesis – which tries to solve the apparentcontradiction between classical and behavioural finance based on evolutionaryeconomics. The course builds heavily on the work of top scientists in the field and shallhelp students to understand investment decisions and to avoid mistakes. Level: Bachelor

This course aims at providing a framework to think about various issues in business from a perspective of economics: horizontal boundaries of the firm; vertical boundaries of the firm; industry analysis; strategic positioning for competitive advantage; sustaining competitive advantage. The students will develop understanding and skills of how to apply economics principles in business strategy. The goal is to enable students to think strategically in a smart way. The course will address basic analytical tools essential for understanding modern business strategy that is of primary importance for Managers and Economists in the modern fast-changing world.

The objective of the course is to introduce main modern strategic frameworks in order to empower students with ideas and insights of how to address strategic decisions in a smart and intelligent way. Strategic intelligence takes the perspective of the CEO/General Manager formulating and implementing strategy in fast-changing environments. The course shows how strategy is developed and turned into action. The course emphasizes the peculiarities of international business as well, and how to sustain competitive advantage in an international environment. Most importantly, it attempts to enable students to think about various strategic tools in a creative and intelligent manner. Classes will be a mixture of lecture and critical discussion of theory and practical cases. Students are expected to spend some time for reading cases in advance.
